metadata.dotPoint: describe proper time (t‚ÇÄ) as the time interval between two events in a reference frame where the two events occur at the same point in space

proper_time_definition.name: Proper Time Definition
proper_time_definition.formula: t‚ÇÄ = time at same spatial point
proper_time_definition.correct: Proper time is the time interval between two events measured by an observer for whom both events occur at the SAME POINT in space.

longest time interval.error: Reversed. Proper time is the SHORTEST measurable time interval.
longest time interval.fix: Proper time is shorter than dilated time. t‚ÇÄ < t always (when Œ≥ > 1).
longest time interval.action: Remember: t = Œ≥t‚ÇÄ and Œ≥ ‚â• 1, so t ‚â• t‚ÇÄ.

time in a stationary frame.error: No frame is absolutely stationary. All motion is relative.
time in a stationary frame.fix: Proper time depends on spatial location of events, not absolute motion.
time in a stationary frame.action: Ask: do both events happen at the same place for this observer?

time measured by any observer.error: Only specific observers measure proper time.
time measured by any observer.fix: Only an observer for whom both events occur at the same location measures proper time.
time measured by any observer.action: Check: are the two events at the same spatial point for this observer?

dilated time.error: Dilated time is observed on a moving clock, not proper time.
dilated time.fix: Proper time = observer's own clock. Dilated time = what they observe on a moving clock.
dilated time.action: Proper = your clock. Dilated = what you see on their clock.

persistent.gap: You are confusing proper time with dilated time or absolute motion.
persistent.action: Focus on spatial location: proper time means both events happen at the SAME PLACE for that observer.

proper_time_same_location.name: Same Spatial Location Criterion
proper_time_same_location.formula: Events at same point ‚Üí proper time
proper_time_same_location.correct: For an observer to measure proper time, both events must occur at the same point in space relative to that observer.

different points in space.error: That describes dilated time, not proper time.
different points in space.fix: Same location = proper time. Different locations = dilated time.
different points in space.action: Proper time: events at ONE place. Dilated time: events at TWO places.

same time.error: Events being simultaneous is different from being at the same location.
same time.fix: Proper time is about spatial location, not temporal coincidence.
same time.action: Two events can be at the same place but different times (proper time).

any location.error: The spatial criterion is essential for proper time.
any location.fix: The defining feature of proper time is both events occurring at ONE spatial location.
any location.action: Always ask: do both events happen at the same spot for this observer?

persistent.gap: You are not applying the spatial criterion correctly.
persistent.action: For each scenario, ask: where does event 1 occur? Where does event 2 occur? Same place = proper time.

dilated_time_definition.name: Dilated Time Definition
dilated_time_definition.correct: Dilated time is what observer P OBSERVES on moving object D's clock. D's seconds appear stretched, so fewer D-seconds elapse as observed by P.

what D experiences.error: D experiences normal proper time, not dilation.
what D experiences.fix: Dilation is observational. D feels completely normal. P observes D's clock running slow.
what D experiences.action: D never feels slowed. Dilation is P's observation ABOUT D.

longer elapsed time for D.error: Dilated time means FEWER seconds pass on D's clock as observed by P.
longer elapsed time for D.fix: D's seconds are stretched (longer), so fewer pass. D ages LESS.
longer elapsed time for D.action: Stretched seconds = fewer of them fit in a given interval = less ageing.

faster clock rate.fix: Moving clocks run slow as observed. D's clock ticks fewer times.
faster clock rate.action: Dilated = stretched = slower ticking = fewer seconds pass.

proper time.error: Dilated time is distinct from proper time.
proper time.fix: Proper time is your own clock. Dilated time is what you observe on a moving clock.
proper time.action: Proper = measured on your clock. Dilated = observed on their clock.

persistent.gap: You are confusing who experiences what in time dilation.
persistent.action: Key insight: D feels normal (proper time). P observes D's clock as slow (dilated). Dilation is observational.

dilated_time_observation.name: Dilation as Observation
dilated_time_observation.correct: Time dilation is what observer P OBSERVES about moving object D's clock. It is not what D experiences.

D's experience.error: D experiences normal proper time in their own frame.
D's experience.fix: D feels completely normal. Only P observes D's clock as running slow.
D's experience.action: Everyone experiences their own time as normal. Dilation is relative.

physical slowing of D.error: D's processes do not physically slow down in D's own frame.
physical slowing of D.fix: D's heartbeat, thoughts, ageing all feel normal to D. P observes them as slower.
physical slowing of D.action: There is no 'real' slowing. It is a relative observation.

absolute effect.fix: Both observers see the OTHER's clock as slow. Neither is 'really' slower.
absolute effect.action: Both P and D are correct in their own frames. Relativity is symmetric.

persistent.gap: You are treating dilation as an absolute physical effect rather than a relative observation.
persistent.action: Dilation is always from an observer's perspective. D never feels slowed. P never feels slowed. Each observes the OTHER as slowed.

stretched_seconds.name: Stretched Seconds Concept
stretched_seconds.correct: D's seconds are dilated (stretched/longer) as observed by P. Because each second is longer, fewer of D's seconds fit into a given P-time interval.

more seconds pass.error: Stretched seconds means FEWER pass, not more.
more seconds pass.fix: If each second is longer, you fit fewer of them into the same interval.
more seconds pass.action: Think: longer ruler markings = fewer fit on the same length.

shorter seconds.fix: Dilation = stretching. D's seconds are observed as longer by P.

same number of seconds.error: Different numbers of seconds elapse in different frames.
same number of seconds.fix: More P-seconds pass than D-seconds during the journey (as observed by P).
same number of seconds.action: t = Œ≥t‚ÇÄ means t > t‚ÇÄ, so more P-seconds than D-seconds.

persistent.gap: You are not connecting 'stretched seconds' to 'fewer seconds elapsing'.
persistent.action: Visualise: if D's seconds are twice as long, only half as many fit in the same P-time interval.

ageing_relationship.name: Ageing and Time Dilation
ageing_relationship.correct: As observed by P, D ages less because fewer D-seconds elapse. D is younger than P after the journey (as observed by P).

D ages more.error: D ages LESS as observed by P, not more.
D ages more.fix: Fewer D-seconds pass (as observed by P) = D ages less = D is younger.
D ages more.action: t‚ÇÄ < t means fewer seconds on D's clock = less ageing for D.

same ageing.error: Different elapsed times mean different ageing.
same ageing.fix: P observes more P-seconds passing than D-seconds, so D ages less.
same ageing.action: If 10 years pass for P but only 2 for D (as observed by P), D is younger.

D feels younger.error: D feels normal. The ageing difference is what P observes.
D feels younger.fix: D experiences normal ageing in D's frame. P observes D as ageing less.
D feels younger.action: D does not feel younger. P observes D as younger.

persistent.gap: You are confusing the observational nature of the ageing difference.
persistent.action: D experiences 2.2 Œºs as normal. P observes 22 Œºs on P's clock while only 2.2 Œºs on D's clock. D is younger to P.

symmetry_of_observation.name: Symmetry of Time Dilation
symmetry_of_observation.formula: P sees D slow; D sees P slow
symmetry_of_observation.correct: Both observers see the OTHER's clock as running slow. P sees D's clock as slow. D sees P's clock as slow. Both observations are correct.

only one observer sees dilation.error: Both observers see the other's clock as slow.
only one observer sees dilation.fix: The situation is symmetric. Each sees the other's clock running slow.
only one observer sees dilation.action: No privileged frame. P sees D slow. D sees P slow. Both are correct.

one clock is really slower.error: Neither clock is 'really' slower in an absolute sense.
one clock is really slower.fix: Time dilation is relative. Each observer's view is equally valid.
one clock is really slower.action: Abandon absolute time. Both observations are correct in their frames.

moving clock is always slow.error: Both clocks are 'moving' relative to each other.
moving clock is always slow.fix: P sees D as moving. D sees P as moving. Each sees the other's clock slow.
moving clock is always slow.action: Motion is relative. Each observer considers themselves at rest.

persistent.gap: You are not grasping the symmetry of special relativity.
persistent.action: Draw both perspectives: P's view (D's clock slow) and D's view (P's clock slow). Both are equally valid.

reference_frame_identification.name: Identifying Reference Frames
reference_frame_identification.correct: To identify who measures proper time, ask: for which observer do both events occur at the same spatial location?

the stationary observer.error: There is no absolute stationary frame.
the stationary observer.fix: Proper time depends on event locations, not absolute motion.
the stationary observer.action: Ask: same place? Not: who is stationary?

the faster observer.error: Speed is relative and does not determine proper time.
the faster observer.fix: Proper time is about spatial coincidence of events, not speed.
the faster observer.action: Focus on where events occur for each observer.

both observers.error: Usually only one observer measures proper time for a given pair of events.
both observers.fix: The observer for whom both events happen at one location measures proper time.
both observers.action: Identify: for whom are both events at the same spot?

persistent.gap: You are using incorrect criteria to identify reference frames.
persistent.action: For any scenario, ask: where does each event occur for each observer? Same place = proper time for that observer.

muon_example.name: Muon Decay Example
muon_example.correct: Earth observes the muon's clock running slow (dilated). The muon experiences 2.2 Œºs of proper time. Earth observes 22 Œºs on Earth's clock while only 2.2 Œºs on muon's clock (for Œ≥ = 10).

muon feels slowed.error: The muon experiences normal proper time. It does not feel slowed.
muon feels slowed.fix: The muon experiences 2.2 Œºs as completely normal. Dilation is Earth's observation.
muon feels slowed.action: The muon does not know its time is dilated. It just exists for 2.2 Œºs.

muon lives longer in its frame.error: The muon lives exactly 2.2 Œºs in its own frame. No change.
muon lives longer in its frame.fix: Earth observes the muon living longer (22 Œºs Earth-time) but the muon still only experiences 2.2 Œºs.
muon lives longer in its frame.action: Muon: 2.2 Œºs proper time. Earth: observes muon clock showing 2.2 Œºs over 22 Œºs of Earth time.

Earth's clock runs slow.error: From Earth's perspective, it is the muon's clock that runs slow.
Earth's clock runs slow.fix: P (Earth) observes D (muon) clock as slow. This is the standard analysis.
Earth's clock runs slow.action: Earth = observer P. Muon = moving object D. P sees D's clock slow.

persistent.gap: You are confusing the perspectives in the muon example.
persistent.action: Earth (P) observes muon (D). D's clock is slow to P. D ages less. Muon experiences 2.2 Œºs normally.

event_location_analysis.name: Analysing Event Locations

event_location_analysis.correct: If both events occur at the same location for an observer, they measure proper time. If at different locations, they measure dilated time.

time determines location.error: Spatial location determines proper vs dilated, not time.
time determines location.fix: Ask about space: same place or different places?
time determines location.action: Events 1 and 2: where do they happen for each observer?

motion determines it.error: Motion is relative. Focus on event locations.
motion determines it.fix: Proper time depends on events being at the same spatial point.
motion determines it.action: Forget who is moving. Ask: same location for events?

always proper time for moving object.error: A moving object measures proper time only if both events occur at their location.
always proper time for moving object.fix: Example: a rocket measures proper time for takeoff and landing if both happen where the rocket is.
always proper time for moving object.action: Check: do both events occur at the object's location?

persistent.gap: You are not correctly analysing event locations.
persistent.action: For each scenario, list: Event 1 location, Event 2 location, for each observer. Same location = proper time.
